reviewText:
A very nice sci-fi sandbox experience, now optimized and without GFWL.
Red Faction Guerrilla's physical destruction engine is truly a fascinating thing. It's like a GTA-lite where you can drive THROUGH buildings. Or walk through them in a huge industrial mech. Or plant lots of explosive charges, detonate them and watch the whole thing collapse. Or just bring it down manually with a hammer :)

With the recent updates (still open beta, but working flawlessly) the game was massively optimized, running at full 60fps without much trouble. It also ditched GFWL, and the developers even included a savegame migration tool to transfer your old GFWL save to Steam Cloud.

Finally, we get the definite version of this game- one that shows how it was meant to look, feel and be played.

reviewText:
Steamworks is here, the great tyrant GFWL is dead and gone! A round of applause is in order for Nordic Games for reviving this wonderful game. Now, on with the review.

Red Faction: Guerrilla is an insanely fun game, let's get that out of the way right now. The open world nature combined with the destructable nature of almost every structure in the game makes for one of the most enjoyable, destructive romps you'll ever have in a game. While you play through the story mode you'll have a wealth of options for how to deal with objectives, many of which involve the destruction of key buildings. Perhaps you'd like to get up close and personal with your hammer, maybe you'd rather hop in a truck and send it flying through the side of a building or you might just hail it with rockets from afar, all of which are perfectly viable options.

Even if you don't wish to go through the campaign it's likely you'll find enjoyment in one of the two other gametypes:

Wrecking Crew - A Solo or Local co-op gamemode with leaderboard integration where you seek to do as much damage to the buildings in a give map with different caveats depending on the mode which are:
Total Chaos - Doing as much damge as possible in one minute with unlimited ammo.
Behemoth - Using one of three Walker (mech) types to do as much damage as possible in a limited time.
Challange - Completing level-specific challanges.
Escalation - You have a limited amount of time and ammo, each round both increase.
Barrel Dash - Destroying as many explosive barrels as you can within the time limit.
Rampage - Deal as much damage as possible with a three minute timelimit, each shot or swing of your weapon takes a set amount of time away.
Internet Game - Go head-to-head with other players in a variet of gamemodes, such as:
Anarchy / Team Anarchy - Your basic Deathmatch mode.
Bagman / Team Bagman - Hold the bag and gain points.
Capture the flag - Exactly what it says on the tin.
Siege - Defend / Attack gamemode where the key is to destroy specific structures.
Damage Control - Fight to capture the three points.
Demolition - Protect the Destroyer, the only person who can damage buildings as they go around and destroy as much as they can.
TL:DR -
The Pros
New Direct X11 support, improved stability, better experience over all thanks to Nordic.
New steamwork intergration, including Matchmaking and achievements.
Strong openworld campaign with plenty to keep you busy.
A host of other activities beyond the campaign that provide many hours of fun.
You can load up a truck with remote mines, send it flying into the side of a building and then detonate it. Awesome.
The Cons
Known technical issues, check the forums and such to see if it'll have any issues with your setup. Many of these are being fixed by Nordic currently, it would seem. Still, it's good to make sure.
While the campaign is fun and story is perfectly acceptable, anyone looking for a great narrative might find it lacking.

reviewText:
GTA on Mars? Well, it may be a little too far-fetched, but it still is true. You have this HUGE map with tons of missions and tons of DESTRUCTIBLE buildings. And the game wants you to cause mayhem and destruction. No mission can be completed without wreaking havoc!

The story is mediocre at best: you play a guy called Mason whose brother has just died. He takes up his role working for the guerrilla, a rebellious group that aims to rid Mars of the oppressive government called EDF. There are some nice cutscenes telling the story but the 20 main missions are not sufficient to make it a great story.

On the other hand: Who cares? The story is just an excuse to destroy everything in your path. As you make progress further areas open up in front of you with the same goal: you must liberate them. Every sector has a morale meter that increases as you complete missions. Higher morale means more assistance from guerrilla members while fighting. Main missions that advance the story can be accessed, too, with the exception of the last one. This particular mission to liberate the sector requires you to decrease enemy morale. Naturally, helping the rebels causes the bad guys lose morale.

Do you like collectibles in games? Well, Red Faction has destructibles. You can prove your worth by looking for high value EDF buildings, piles of ore, propaganda signs and practically anything else that belongs to Mars' evil faction. Side missions are also many and varied as one would expect: you can catch couriers, protect allied areas, take vehicles to safe locations or - and this is my favourite - ride shotgun with Jenkins. The guy drives but you are manning the gun: just shoot at everything that belongs to EDF - buildings, vehicles and anything that increases the counter on the upper right-hand side of the screen telling you how much damage you have caused. Once you have reached 1 billion credits another achievement pops up.

I like how varied the environment is. You would think the entire game swims in brownish-reddish colours. No! New sectors have a newer, more different look. Oasis has green areas with fewer but bigger buildings telling you this is where the upper class of Mars lives. The Badlands have a more evil look with the presence of the mysterious marauders - you can clearly see this is an homage to Mad Max!

A good way to encourage the player to cause destruction is the currency introduced: every collapsed building leaves scrap metal. These shiny, light blue pieces of salvage can then be used to buy newer weapons or upgrade the existing ones.

I understand the Steam Edition of the game has a lot of new features. This is certainly a plus - I played this well after it finally ditched the awful GFWL service. It is a good thing that more and more games do the same!

To summarise: Red Faction is a game about destruction. There's nothing more satisfying than leaving the office after a long and hard day and using Mason's sledgehammer to off some Martian bad guys or to destroy a tower. And if you truly want to destroy everything dozens of hours of fun is guaranteed!

reviewText:
Finishe Red Faction: Guerrilla on Casual difficulty, took me around 10-12 hours, and I unlocked 13 out of 50 achievements.

A damn good game, while the story doesn't do much to inspire a whole lot of interest, the gameplay and destruction carry the game and make it into something special, it embodies everyones desire to blow things up and cause mayhem, while watching the thing you destroyed crumble infront of you in a surprisingly realistic way. With the recent Steamworks patch, there's no greater time to jump into Red Faction: Guerrilla and have a fun, destructive, albiet slightly bare gameplay experience.

+Destruction, destruction, destruction
+Gameplay is enhanced by the need to think strategically about how to approach a situation with the games destruction engine
+Cool and unique weapons, that enhance the destruction
+Did I say the destruction was awesome? Because it is, by far the star of the game

-Story is typical sci-fi, rebellion, unneccesary love interest stuff you see in every made for TV SyFy movie
-Enemies can be annoying to fight, sometimes you just want to drive around and hit stuff with a hammer without a squad of EDF goons shooting at you.
-Kind of flat in the open world department, it has side stuff, but nothing super intersing and the world seems built just to be blow up, with weird empty archtecture and barren areas with little to no civilians.

Overall it's a great game that deserves and play just for the fun of the destruction and the many ways you can lay waste to Mars.

8 out of 10

reviewText:
A short history of RF:G No I am not going to spell out its full name because I cannot properly spell Guerrilla. Its double R and double L I know but no. No full name. Anyways back to the history, RF:G was originally released with Games With Windows Live integrated. That means no cheats, lots of issues regarding login and etc etc and we have tons of weird graphical problem that made this game not very well known. Thankfully the Steam port has been optimized and there is no more GFWL. Thank god. My pc went from 20fps to 60 stable fps.

Game Info Name: Red Faction : Guerrilla
Developer: A lot of people, this game has been brought out by Nordic Games after the fall of THQ. RIP.
Genre: Smasing, Action, Open World, Guerrilla Warfare
Personal Thoughts: Good game although there are parts that they did right and parts that they did wrong.

What is Red Faction: Guerrilla? A game about a guy who lost his brother and so join a rebel insurgency fighting back against the military. ON MARS! That means super wonky vehicle, unrealistic weapons and building that crumbles at the drop of a hat. Everything you see saved for some things are completely destructible using the force of vehicle, hammer and explosive! But dear god the story is wonky even though it make sense like the Dev tried stretching a lump dough too thinly trying to cover the whole baking table with it. But well at least the game is fun enough to cover that slight defect.

Sound
Main character grunts a lot, gun doesn't pack any power in them although we can excuse it by saying in the future recoil proofing technology has improved. The most powerful anti infantry still sounds like the usual sci fi pew pew pew. Hardly any music in this game but one good thing is at least vehicle grunt properly instead of purring like a cat.

Graphic
Everything look so brown especially the first and third area. Especially the first area because when you exit the town you will see that there is literally a change in the overall saturation of the game. Also I have to state that I used the DX9 backend instead of the DX11 because it still runs badly on my computer merely just to add more reflection and glaring elements.

Gameplay
Fun game, you have a hammer from early on that can be used to smash buildings to pieces which is useful since every single building in the game is smashable and since it follows the laws of physics it is completely pointless to destroy the top part of the building since destroying the bottom part will quickly bring it down.

Why destroying building you ask? For money to get salvages duh. Salvages used to upgrade the Main Character from a big man with a hammer to a big man with a hammer and 20 kilos of metal strapped to him with a full blow rocket launcher on his back and an exotic martian weapon by his side.

The main game of RF:G has you filling a meter and emptying out a meter. The filling one is the morale meter where killing military unit quickly, destroying propaganda and helping out the rebel will fill it. This serves mainly to get more money when doing story mission and for receiving backup which you will seriously need later on. At maximum rate you will get 4 people fighting by your side.

The other meter is military control meter where you need to make it zero to unlock story mission and I can't confirm if making zero affects the military hardware they throw at you. Maybe not because I still get tanks and humvee trying to ram me even when the bar is full. You make it go down by destroying military stuff.

There are side activities that helps you with lowering those bar as well and they are generally pretty fun mayhem filled things to do that ranges from assaulting base, drive by mission and explosive mission. Generally fun enough. Good thing the story mission is as good as the side mission! Because the story is weak.

EDIT: Forgot Vehicle
Vehicle are so tough even your basic buggy can break through concrete wall, lets not even talk about the APC that can smash straight through a building clean. Although they do handle terribly and tend to float all over the place if you hit a bump they're good enough I guess. Also you can change the orientation of your vehicle while in midair so pretty much you can with a bit of practice land perfectly fine on the ground.

And that's pretty much for the gameplay, there's stuff to collect, people to rescue and the usual fanfare of open world stuff although some upgrades are evil enough locked behind doing side missions! So go complete them otherwise you won't get some of the gear.

SPECIAL SECTION
THE STORY!
Pretty much does not suck but is jarring as hell. You see character usually make one appearances then were gone just like that.

Conclusion Yeah it's a fun game where you really are being a Guerrilla Fighter against a military forces. And you do get a lot of toys to play with. Well destroying building never gets old I guess but the story really rubs me the wrong way. Anyways lets wrap this up. RF:G a fun game from a publisher that is legendary in the industries but is no more. Buy this game now that it has steam support.

Tips
Late game weapons are game breaking,
Always be on the run.
Just climb on top of that humvee and smash his face in with the hammer. No need to waste ammo shooting the gunner.
Always when faced with demolition mission or assault mission use APC to smash through building, Usually they can go right through it.

Scoring Methology [Courtesy of Meat King]:
-	S-Rank: excellent
-	A-Rank: very good
-	B-Rank: solid
-	C-Rank: satisfactory
-	D-Rank: inferior

Verdict: A-Rank

reviewText:
8/10
Overview: 3rd Person Open World

The Good:

+ Technically the game holds up extremely well, graphics still look nice and the game runs very smoothly despite all the destruction and chaos happening.

+ The open world of Mars is split into different sectors. Each sector has its own unique setting and look to it. The developers made good use of color hues to really differentiate the different areas.

+ The sense of destruction in the game is some of the best I've seen in a game to date with very few games matching it. Just about everything that is seen in the game can be destroyed with your sledgehammer, blown up with explosive or shot with rockets. Seeing large buildings crumbling down with debris flying everywhere is very satisfying.

+ Variety of weapons that fit your play style

+ Side missions are varied and provide a nice change of pace from the main game. 2 of the main side missions is destruction and transportation. In destruction you have to destroy a building given limited weapons and time. In transportation you have to drive a vehicle to a destination within a time limit.

+ As you destroy enemy buildings and complete side/main missions you raise morale allowing more AI to fight alongside with you and gain more ammo from crates. Although it doesn't make the biggest difference in the world it is a nice system given the context of the story.

+ The game comes with bonus single player DLC which extends the game

+ In addition to single player, Wrecking Crew mode allows you to play a different levels with a variety of different options either by yourself or with others to try and get a high score. A fun, optional mode that extends your playtime.

+ Removed games for windows live

The Average:

I found the main missions to be pretty average. Most main missions have you going to a certain location and blowing everything up. I would have liked to see more variety among them.
Because of the lack of variety in main missions, sometimes the game can feel a bit repetitive.


The Bad:

- Like past Red Faction games the story and characters are forgettable and one dimensional. The story serves as an excuse to blow things up and nothing more. A lot of wasted potential here which is sad given some of the cool locations.

- I hear multiplayer is fun, too bad the community is gone.

Conclusion:

This is a good mindless fun game that reminded me of Just Cause 2. You go around blowing things up and watch the destruction unfold as you fight wave of enemies attacking you. I am fairly new to this series only having beaten the other two games a few months ago. This is a very interesting series. Red Faction started out as a linear first person shooter, then it became a level based shooter with bosses and then it became a third person open world game. If you love blowing things up then look no further than this game.

reviewText:
A technical masterpiece with few equals. Red Faction: Guerrilla accomplishes something very few games have ever tried, much less achieved with real success; dynamic destruction with full physics and few - if any - slowdowns accompanying them. While the game is not perfect and even its destruction system can be finicky at times, Guerrilla is a game that I wish had inspired other developers to follow suit.

The centerpiece of the experience is the Geo-Mod component of the game that handles dynamic building destruction. From my experience, little comes close to the level of optimization, stability, and overall fidelity that Geo-Mod enables for Red Faction. Practically every building in the game can be demolished in a maddening variety of ways. Strategically knock out primary supports and let the roof cave in, demolish a wall and watch the building topple sideways, or just ram a tank or a few demolitions charges in the front door and let the chaos unfold. Even with hundreds of individual pieces of a structure smashing to the ground and causing even more death or destruction in their descent, the game runs butter-smooth in all but the most catastrophic of collapses.

It isn't just Geo-Mod alone that makes the building destruction fantastic, but how the game is set up. From the beginning, Guerrilla understands that demolishing buildings is a core element of the game and incorporates it into everything from sandbox shootouts to evasion missions. Stuck in a corner with bad cover or no ammo? Whip out your sledgehammer and knock a hole in the wall that's got you trapped. Taking fire from a difficult target on a balcony? Chuck a demo charge onto the bottom and bring the floor out from underneath him. Horde of APCs charging over a bridge? Blast a hole in their path and watch them tear apart the bridge's supports on the way down.

Unfortunately, all games pay for quality in some area or another. Guerrilla suffers in several. While its shortcomings rarely fall below a professional grade of quality, Guerrilla struggles notably in its writing and offers a fairly light, two-dimensional plot with an antagonist that's almost on par with zombies in lack of characterization and absurdity. Characters on both sides of the firing line aren't developed beyond their basic introductions and the conclusion of the story itself is predictable, at best. The game's wonderful soundtrack almost feels like wasted potential as a result.

Combat, graphics, and post-story sandbox activities are smaller failings, but are thankfully not quite as mediocre as the game's story. Gunfighting suffers from enemies lacking satisfying hit feedback and a reliance on weight of numbers and spongy health instead of engaging or varied behavior. The player's arsenal likewise suffers from severe maximum ammunition limits, forcing many weapon switches or battlefield pick-ups to stay competitive. Interplay with the game's destructive environment, good player mobility, and a wealth of available weapons shore up the otherwise forgettable combat, but only enough to keep it from being a chore.

Graphically, the game isn't quite up to snuff, but this is understandable given its sandbox nature and physics-heavy environment. Textures are low resolution, models often lack in style or quality, and animations are mixed bag of stiff movement compensated" by high playback speed. Lighting is often strange inside buildings and the game's low texture resolution is regularly given its own "compensation" with aggressive tiling where applicable. Fortunately
date: the Geo-Mod system is again of note; its effects
hoursPlayed: and behavior make for a stunning experience watching buildings collapse.\n\nOverall

Definitely worth the full price.

reviewText:
Red Faction Guerrilla Steam Edition is a one of a kind Military based shooter. I normally am not one that always plays shooters constantly so this game gave me a change of pace with a great level of difficulty from the very start.  The whole purpose of the game is to try to take over control points to stop this evil organization that has killed many people. In order to take control of these sections of the game you will have to bring down small and then large heavily fortified buildings.

There is little to hardly no cover system so often you may need  to shoot small packs of enemies and then retreat for a bit to get your health meter back up which automatically regenerates and then head right back over that way to finish your mission.  There is a wide variety between the tpes of vehicles you can hop in to remain safe from the opposing faction. The first consists of your normal vehicles you can only drive and have no weapon attachments. You can generally hop in any vehicle even if a civilian or the military organization your taking down is in it. Sometimes this will require you to shoot  them off the turrent based military vehicles so then you can invade control points easier.

In my own opinion wrecking crew mode is the greatest feature of all because it has no story and you just follow short  objectives like blowing up barrels to demolish buildings, using walkers to just obliterate everything standing in your way in what is known as Total chaos mode which is just a free-for-all destroy type of mode within wrecking crew.

My favorite part about this game is the use of Walkers to demolish control points if you are lucky enough to find one. There are usually a few different types but only one that has missles which is something similar to something that would be seen in a Armored core game or even generally comparable to a Star Wars AT-AT walker though smaller.

I'll give this game a solid 8.5/10.  I highly recommend you check it out. It is made by THQ which was a company that went bankrupt eventually after having games only targeting family friendly kids games, movies games and then they created fully Muture games which was primarily targeted towards adults though that did not help their downfall as a company.

All in all the destructible environments reminded me of some videos I have seen where people play the Battlefield Shooter series.

reviewText:
The environmental damage takes centre stage in this game, buildings can be torn down piece by piece, they have weaknesses to their architectural structure, and other surfaces can be smashed and mutilated. The environment always feels alive, the wind blows dust across your path and howls gently, the EDF are always carrying out patrol routes and intimidating civilians, then we have the safe houses where your fellow faction members are deep in conversation and planning their next moves. There are various sectors to explore, each with their own distinct look and feel. You will start your journey in a quieter and more open desert area, then move to a rocky wasteland, and venture across more urban and densely populated areas.
Environmental design has also been taken into consideration, there are some vast open areas but all of the sectors are connected well and just as easy to navigate. In-game character models are well crafted and animations perform competently as the gameplay pushes the boundaries of pure carnage. The soundtrack deserves praise as it matches the ambient nature of Mars.
The story missions revolve around helping the Red Faction overthrow the EDF and liberate each sector; once a sector is free of EDF control then no enemy forces will bother you in that zone. A lot of the time you are outnumbered and it isn't always easy to take out specific targets. The A.l. for your guerrilla allies can be really clumsy at times, some missions require you to free captured guerrilla fighters and get them to safety. For some reason, sometimes they donâ€™t wish to get in a getaway car with you and end up fending off enemy forces at their own demise. Perhaps it would have helped having some greater control over freedom fighters.

reviewText:
Red Faction Guerilla Steam Edition is a great open-world game that excels at destruction.
You play as Alec Mason, an Earth-born miner that comes to Mars looking for a job. Soon after your arrival, you get involved in a guerilla war against the oppressing force - Earth Defense Force. Your mission is to weaken EDF's control over different regions by destroying key buildings and completing optional tasks. Once you lower the control over a region, 3-4 story missions unlock for every region, so there is a little grinding involved for progression. Bring EDF's control to 0 in a region and you can take it over.

The gameplay is focused on destruction, as it should be because this game uses a very nice physics engine. There are a lot of tools to blow things up: items in the environment, mines, placeable detonators, rocket launcher, etc. You even get rewarded with scrap (game currency) for bringing down structures and making stuff go boom. There are also regular guns such as a pistol and assault riffle, but these are less fun to use. Later in the game you will have access to better guns and gadgets, but you will need a big amount of scrap if you want to unlock everything. My favourite combination was sniping with the nano-rifle from mid-air (using jetpack).

I didn't play Red Faction Guerilla in its original itteration, but from the information available it looks like the developers cared enough for the game to improve a lot and re-release it in a better state.

If you like open-world games such as Saints Row, Just Cause or Max Mad then it is a must-play. If not, I would still recommend to give this one a try. You will have a blast, I promise.

reviewText: Red Faction Guerrilla is now free of GFWL! If sandbox style, open world play is your thing, I thoroughly recommend Red Faction Guerrilla. While it's getting a bit long in the tooth these days, both visually and mechanically, it's still a great game for tooling about and destroying things.\n\nWhile this is one of my favourite sandbox games, my recommendation comes with a cople of caveats; mission checkpointing can be a little harsh at times, and the game really is mostly about choosing your own way of doing the missions you're given. There is a story, and there are many, many missions. But the true joy is in deciding how to approach a given challenge with all the tools the game provides, especially in terms of destructibility. And when you screw up, you're sent back to the beginning of a mission, so repetition is virtually inevitable. Therefore, if you like your game experiences more towards the curated end of the spectrum, I can't extend this recommendation to you. This is very much a game that lets to find your own fun in a science fiction world, but helps that along by providing tools of sheer destructive joy.

reviewText:
There aren't a lot of games like Red Faction: Guerrilla out there but I've got to say I loved it.

The game's emphasis is basically centered around blowing stuff. And carnage. And blowing some more stuff up. I lost count of how many times I just went on rampages throughout the various sectors, trying to destroy key strategic places while having the EDF on my â™¥â™¥â™¥ trying to stop me. The fully destructible environments and buildings just give you such an amazing sense of freedom and endless shortcut potential. Combine that with the possibility of driving overpowered mechs and tanks, and you've got a really fun game to just mess about.

It is also open world, so there's plenty of side missions here and there, and unmarked collectibles, but this made me recall the first Assassin's Creed, and not in a good way. See, while there are several types of side missions, every time you visit a new sector, you just end up getting the same side missions anyway. You really just end up feeling like you're doing the same thing over and over again even when you're in a new zone, just like Assassin's Creed. There's a few dynamic ones that pop up when you might just be wandering around, but again, not a lot of variety.

I absolutely love Colonial Mars. You don't see it depicted often, and it is that sweet blend of early colonization + open expanses of wilderness. The sectors themselves, of which there are quite a few, do have their own personality and flavor. The whole vibe it gave off really reminded me of driving the Mako in Mass Effect.

The plot itself is pretty standard really, usual insurgent rebels fighting evil empire with superior forces. There were a few plot twists here and there but I found most of it, including the story missions, rather underwhelming. Personally though, the freedom fighter premise is something that never really gets old for me, so I did enjoy it nevertheless.

All in all though, totally recommend this one. While it may not be thought provoking long after you've beaten it, you will remember the slaughter you've inflicted as your carefully planted bombs collapse that huge apartment block in one go, causing its floors to crash on the enemies' unsuspecting heads as you break a hole in a wall to cut a shortcut and make your escape. Fun stuff.

IF YOU'RE HAVING PROBLEMS, READ THIS:
A lot of people have complained online about the weird graphical glitches and performance problems. The most common glitches are constant sunrays through walls, flickering objects and dissapearing objects. This is a problem with Direct X 10. To fix this, you need to launch the game in Direct X 9. Follow these steps:
1.) Right-click the game in your Steam library and click properties.
2.) Now click Set Launch Options".
3.) Enter this text in the field that is shown: -nod3d10
4.) Click OK.
This should also make the game lag much less.

reviewText:
Red Faction Guerrilla is the other masterpiece from Volition (Freespace being the first.)
This game hits all the right notes and lets you do what you like once you learn how to thoroughly â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ of the Man (EDF). As much as I have enjoyed Saint's Row the Third and IV, this is a more fun sandbox experience. There is nothing like demolishing building after building, then running away or fighting the swarms that come to pacify you.
The multiplayer is awesome, though you need to coordinate with others to play, since you must have a full roster to launch. But no other game gives you such an arsenal or destructable arena to smack people around in. For the longest time this game was out of reach on PC due to the GFWL abomination. Even while that was 'online' it took herculean effort for me to get the game to launch. Now that is in the past, thanks to the efforts of some clear-visioned coders.
I cannot wait to play through this game again, and lay down some singularity bombs to suck my friends into who knows what online.

reviewText:
Red Faction Guerrilla is an amazing game by Volition, and they decided to make a sandbox game as opposed to a linear first person shooter.

What Guerrilla brings to the table is it's primary selling point, it's destruction system. Which is so well implemented I'm extremely surprised it was never really focused on in games since then. The game allows you to destroy literally every building in the game with it's revolutionary destruction mechanic. All the buildings are built with foundations, levels and fall apart due to the strain of gravity. So it takes a great deal of strategy inorder to destroy a building using as minimal resources as possible.

Indeed much of the mission structure and sidequests in the game revolve entirely around the destruction mechanic. Add to that it has an engaging world to explore. Full of little niche references to the original while maintaining a totally different stylistic design. There are of course elements from other games like cars and firefights but it pales in comparison to the well incorporated destruction mechanic. Believe me, once you destroy your first building you will go on an odyssey to return Mars back to a desolate wasteland.

Thankfully RFG has had Games For Windows Live patched out. So now you can play it and it's multiplayer properly. I can't recommend this game enough.

reviewText:
The destruction system is excellent, causing havoc feels great, there are dozens of weapons each with its own upgrades, side-quests are fun and the voice acting is nice. Awesome!

What's not so awesome is the characters, the music, the AI and the story...

The characters are easily forgettable and the story feels weak mainly because the good guys win only thanks to the main character (who's just some generic dude). The EDF aren't that hard to beat either (I played on Normal).The game also talks about some Marauders during the beginning, but they only appear twice in the story. Some interesting events happen throughout the story every now and then, thankfully.

The AI is dumb, but at least it's funny watching the enemies and allies do weird stuff sometimes. The music is there, but nothing really stands out. Everything sounds the same and it's usually hard to even hear the music, because of all the loud noises (fighting EDF, blowing up stuff, etc.)

One last big annoyance is the the ore crystals & the EDF crates. There are way too many crystals and crates and they are all too far away from each other. The rewards you get for destroying them are also negligible. 6-12 salvage per crystal and about as much per crate? That's it? If there were fewer of them, but rewarded more salvage (and maybe even stuff other than salvage, like unique weapons or temporary buffs, or discounts to certain upgrades) then maybe it would've been fun destroying them all.

Despite its flaws it's a good game. Even better now that GFWL is dead! Definitely worth playing!

reviewText:
Red Faction Guerrilla is an open world sand box game with an interesting narrative and fantastic amounts of playability.
Open world games are certainly not my kind of game, however this game excels in the fact there is a linear, developing plot as you progress from story mission to story mission, without this, the game would have been a flop in my honest opinion.

The game didn't hook me at first, but the moment they put a gun in my hands, and I was fighting hordes of EDF soldiers, that's when I started to become hooked. The gun play feels refreshing, impactful and enjoyable. That and the fact that it isn't your stereotypical cover shooter... because the cover will just get blown up! It's great that for once, the best way to play is aggressively, it really helps make it refreshing.

the game heavily features driving segments, and they aren't F-zero GX quality driving segments either. This would hinder the game, but it actually helps a lot. It gives you time to immerse yourself into the game and the game world. Eventually you do get a fast transport system, which is fantastic, but you still need to drive to your destinations. This combined with the raid missions which have colonists hop in your vehicle, makes the driving all the more pleasant.

And on the topic of colonists, this is where the game truly shines. You can sing praises on the destruction physics, but what really makes this game amazing in my eyes, is the Morale and NPC interactions. As you fight the EDF and complete objectives, more and more colonists will fight by your side. One particular cause of this, is the EDF assault missions, where EDF Armoured personal carriers and tanks drive into a colonist base, and you must fight them off. As your Morale increases, more and more of these NPC's fight by your side, it makes the world feel real, and helps really show that the mission your doing actually have weight behind them. The morale goes as far to change the dialog of the NPC's when you walk past them, which is truly the icing on the cake for me.

The games plot is nothing to write home about, but the game does a great job immersing yourself in the world at least, thanks to features like the Morale system, as described earlier.  The mission variety also helps a lot in keeping the game interesting. The Jenkins missions are a little bit boring by the end, as its basically a gallery turret segment, and timed driving segments would have been better if the driving itself was more enjoyable, but it is what it is. The two artillery segments towards the end where mediocre at best, but they weren't bad, I'm glad they were included just to spice things up a little right at the end, but I would have preferred to only have had that segment played once, and not twice.

However, the expanding diversity of guns and upgrades, and the dynamic, highly entertaining Havok physics engine made this game a stellar experience. A fantastic game, definitely worth the time and effort (and of course the money) to play, you will (probably) not regret it!

reviewText:
This is a game I did not pay any attention to or notice until there was a free weekend, I was almost not going to try it out as I have heaps of games Iam yet to play. But I tried it and played through the start and was immediately hooked and had to buy it even though I wanted to play other games first.

I love games where you get to destroy your surroundings I always find them so much fun.
And there are so very few games like that. The only other game I played that was sort of like that was Just Cause 2.

I enjoy this game a lot. Blow up entire buildings, destroy everything around you with explosives, sledgehammer and even your vehicle, what more could you want?

It also has decent combat, and side missions that test your skills such as beating the time for demolitions master which you have various scenarios such as find the buildings weak spot, destroy it with 1 explosive and beat the pro time of 15 seconds, or destroy this building as quick as possible just using your sledgehammer as well as various others.

There's also transporter challenge of getting a vehicle somewhere as quick as possible. But I find those boring. I dislike vehicle controls so found it rather frustrating doing transporter missions.
And some others as  such as raids, rescue etc.

The story and characters aren't much, but I don't mind as destroying everything is what the focus of the game is and I can't get enough of that. Once I start destroying I get so immersed and can't stop.

I really like the futuristic look to some vehicles and buildings. The music is very good. Though the landscape looks rather bland and barren being mountainous and dusty, but I guess that's what you get with Mars.
Did not have any problems or bugs with this game and like that the world feels very open and not boxed in

It's great that when morale is high guerilla's join you and help attack the enemy and they can be helpful when trying to destroy things they can draw the enemies focus so I can destroy things easier, but they also can be a hindrance and get in the way of explosions and hammer swings.

This is a great game for those who love destruction and I did not start to feel bored until after the 46 hour mark which is good.

What I disliked most was that you get such a small amount of ammo, even with full upgrade.


Awesome fun and a must play. Doesn't quite get an 8 as there is not much variety in what you do.

7/10

reviewText:
Download size: about 8 GB
Playtime: about 12 hours for single player

The newly updated Red Faction Guerilla steam edition comes with trading cards and achievements since they migrated away from Games For Windows Live. It also seems to be less buggy, but this may be a coincidence. You donâ€™t need to have played the previous Red Faction games to understand whatâ€™s going on, and if you played Red Faction Armageddon, the campaign story isnâ€™t really spoiled for you either. The stories take place with enough time in between for all sorts of things to have happened.

You play as Alec Mason, a recent immigrant to Mars planning to live with his brother as a miner (actually a scavenger of salvage). Unfortunately your plans are ruined when you experience the brutality of the EDF (Earth Defense Fleet), the powerful military organization that seems to be in the pocket of all the major corporations keeping the working man down. Alec joins the Red Faction, which is a kind of resistance/terrorist group committed to driving the EDF off of Mars by any means necessary. So now you (as Alec) spend your time blowing things up (and collecting salvage).

Red Faction Guerilla is a third person open world game, similar to Grand Theft Auto or the Saints Row games. Since it takes place on Mars, thereâ€™s also reduced gravity though you donâ€™t really get to fly around everywhere, even after you get a jet pack. The trademark of all Red Faction games is destructible environments, so like Red Faction Armageddon, you can pretty much destroy any man-made structure in the game, including buildings, bridges, walls, and all the crates the EDF leaves lying around. There are a few things that might give you trouble, for example some buildings have indestructible metal girders as part of the construction, but you can still knock them around and cause the buildings to collapse. Itâ€™s probably easiest to just ram your cars into the buildings though. Yes, like Grand Theft Auto and Saints Row, you can hijack all sorts of cars (no aircraft) and drive all over the map. The game world is moderately large and probably would take 15 minutes of straight driving to get across it. You canâ€™t do that though since Mars has mountains and valleys blocking you so you mostly need to follow roads.

You can carry up to 4 weapons at a time, but one of them is locked as your trusty sledgehammer, which is decent for destroying buildings. There isnâ€™t too much variety in the projectile weapons, and youâ€™ll probably stick will explosive weapons in order to bring down buildings. Weapons and their upgrades are unlocked in the game by completing side missions or just picking them up from fallen enemies. Once youâ€™ve unlocked the weapon you can restock it from any of your â€œsafe housesâ€ around the map. Money in the game is salvage, which shows up as shiny metal that you can pick up by walking over. Most of your salvage will likely come from completing missions, but a thereâ€™s a lot to be gained from the rubble of buildings.
Pros:
+Wreck buildings in all sorts of ways. Usually the quickest way is using explosive weaponry, which has ammo limitations, so I like to try and crash cars into the buildings whenever possible. Just make sure you have enough room to build up ramming speed (and enough firepower to survive the EDF retaliation).
+The game has multi player which I only dabbled in for about an hour. There are actually people still playing but not more than a dozen or so at a time. No co-op campaign play however, which is a shame. There are a lot of multi-player modes, but people only seem to be playing the deathmatch types.

Cons
-Unfortunately for me, a large number of the gameâ€™s Steam achievements are for grinding in multiplayer, and a bunch of the single player achievements require finding ALL of certain types of collectibles.
-The gameâ€™s side quests become repetitive after a while and by the time you unlock the gameâ€™s final area, you probably wonâ€™t be doing any of the side quests since youâ€™ll be bored by then.
-For an older game, my computer actually heats up when I play for a while. The game uses Havok engine, which seems to appear in a ton of the games Iâ€™ve been playing recently, but the gameâ€™s graphics arenâ€™t much better than say, Fallout 3.

All in all Red Faction Guerilla is a good game worth your weekend to play through. The campaign has its exciting points and itâ€™s fun to go around blowing up buildings. The DLC Demons of the Badlands is included in the Steam edition (I donâ€™t know if the GFWL version had it). The DLC is about 3 hours and includes a few new weapons to play with, as well as a completely useless new kind of collectible (battery packs that donâ€™t do anything). At least in the main game, all the collectibles had some sort of benefit (like give you a little salvage).

reviewText:
YOU BLABBED BIRDMEAT! YOU BLABBED ABOUT MARS!

Hi this is me, Birdmeat, and here is me making a recommendation for Red Faction. Its a third person shooter about how THE EVIL EARTH FEDERATION opresses the GOOD PEOPLE OF MARS. You become Space Che Guevara by sabotaging Federation buildings, wich is great fun. You have an absurdly powerful hammer and remote charges at first, and more exotic weapons later, but to be fair, nothing beats the hammer and the charges...except for a car..loaded with charges..launched into the building with the hammer. The destruction physics are really nice, even tough buildings manage to stand upright with only 1 supportive wall for a long time, but I guess that can be blamed on MARS GRAVITY. Our hero, Mr. Alec Mason person, is rather boring. All characters are, actualy. The story is meh, it kept me playing as you unlock new areas that way, but it is really a generic revenge-rebelion story.

Ha ha ha, you think this is the real recommendation...?
..IT IS!

reviewText:
This is game is hands down one of my most favorite games ever and heres why:

1.) Full destructible (and rebuildable) enviorments using Unreal tournament/Halo style weapons

2.) Very fun single player campaign

3.) The multiplayer. Has to be one of my most favorite online 3rd person fps games to date. If you enjoy Halo, Gears of War, Unreal Tournament, Counterstrike, Team fortress, I highly recommend this game.

4.) The Steam Edition removes the need for Games for Windows Live.

All in all this is one gem of a game. I played for over 400+ hours on the ps3 version of this game when it was first released 4 years ago. This is a great game and i recommend it to everyone espicially when its on sale ($2.99 when i purchased)

reviewText:
Pros:
+ awesome destruction engine
+ fun gunplay
+ fun story/side missions
+ awesome weapons
+ solid driving physics
+ fairly open world
+ neat graphics and effects
+ gameplay that rewards planning and strategy
+ good story

Cons:
- no saves during missions

This game is fantastic! It's made by the same guys who made Saints Row and it feels alot like it. So if you liked Saints Row and you love to destroy things, this is the game for you! Literally EVERYTHING can be destroyed. Buildings, radio towers, billboards, bridges etc......

The in game map is fairly big and open. I never feel like im being restricted by invisible walls. The game is packed with side missions and diversion that are all varied and fun to play. The story missions are a blast to play. Though the story itself is a bit basic, it's still pretty good and sets up a good premise for the game.

GFWL has been purged from this game so now is the best time to buy it. If you wait for it to go on sale you can pick it up for $5-$10 which is an amazing value for how much content you get.

9/10

reviewText:
Smash buildings and hit people in the face with a sledgehammer.  Whats not to like.

On a more serious note the damage model makes the game.  There's a few issues with the graphics under DX10 but these can be fixed by running in DX9 mode.   There's a few threads on how to fix DX10, but none worked for me with the remaining suggestions covering all sorts of things with the potential to break your system.  TBH not worth the effort and DX9 mode only means a few extra graphical effects are missing, nothing major.

The selection of weapons in the game complement the smash-it-up feel and the AI's acceptable.  Played through till the end and enjoyed the lot.  One thing to note a lot of the screenshots on the store didn't really seem to accurately show what single player is like (I never once saw a flying vehicle close up like the screenshots show).

The only real issue is it is a GFWL title with all the baggage thats brings.  Personally had no problems with this but many others seem to have, and of course there's no guarantee how much longer GFWL will remain around so play it while you can.

Want the best RF game? get this!

reviewText:
Put 60+ hours into this on PS3 and polished off most of the trophies; then bought it for PC. It is worth the full price, every penny well spent.
Far from perfect (friendly AI is more pain than help, slow upgrades at the begining, dull story etc), but this title offers something special that top rated games so often lack. Many reviews mentioned the destruction which is awsome, especially with the weapon unlocked after liberating the second area. But for me, the best is the thrill of multi million mayhem, hit and run guerilla attacks on really high security enemy installations. Spiced with killing sprees on the getaway, and making it home with -100 control and +20 moral. That is priceless. Of course on hard difficulty.
Main quest missions can be a chore, but the side missions (demolition, transporter, house arrest) are mostly awesome.
Highly recommended.

reviewText:
This game is kind of like Mad Max, but In my opinion this is better, but I really have no right saying that, because they're similar but different. I'll explain why.

Mad Max qualities:

+Action Pact Fun
+Car racing destruction
+Great Psychics
+Massively well made
+Missions
+Graphics

Red Faction Guerrilla's Qualities:

+Action
+Car Action
+Missions
+Destructibility
+Graphics
+Reputability-Multi-player

Now, how are they different, and how are they similar? Easy!

Similarities:
-The Map physics are alike
-Both have really good graphics.
-Both have car travel
-Both have lots of action
-Both campaigns are based around missions,

Differences:

-The Destructibility for Mad Max is for cars, but Red Faction Guerrilla's is houses, buildings, and more, but not much destructibility for cars.
-Mad Max action is mostly fists, Guerrilla's is mostly a Hammer, or Machine gun.
Guerrilla's Car action is mostly running away, it isn't meant for ramming and destroying other cars, It's to get to the mission quicker, or to run away. Mad Max's is for the same reason, but also ramming and destroying other cars, and running over people.

Mad Max and Guerrilla are both amazing games, Guerrilla is better if you have a lower budget, because it's a lot cheaper.

reviewText:
Back when the game came out i never managed to properly play it, since the first PC version which used GFWL was just a mess but that has finally changed.

No more Games For Windows Live instead it uses Steam now, lots of bug fixes, better optimization,updated compatibilaty with latest Windows OS',Steamworks achievements,Steam powered Multiplayer and DX10 replaced with DX11.


Destructability in this game is still the best we've ever had in gaming to date, yeah texture quality,polygon count and lighting effects are now somewhat dated but it still look pretty solid visualy even for today's standarts, in my opinion at least.

Gunplay doesn't really feel all that good, missions are very repetetive, side missions are just the same 3-5 missions repeated 100 times in the open world of Mars and since it's Mars, most of the enviroment is of course the same which makes it somewhat dull to look at, as you roll into a new sector to liberate just for it to look almost the same as the last place and the story is forgetable and not worth paying attention to.

However the thing that holds this game is the what i mentioned earlier on, the amazing destructibility, watching as every lil' piece of a big building colides into another big building, all parts reacting properly and than crumbling into tiny bits is just a blissful joy to watch and makes me wish we had more games with such an amazing destructo physics engine.
It's totally worth picking up just because of this amazing tech, it's so much fun slaming a giant truck into a military base filled with explosives and then detonating it and watching it all blow up in a wonderfull way.

The game is only 9.99 Euros and during sales it drops to just 4 euros, sometimes even only 1.50 Euros and it's well worth the lil' amount of money it asks from you, even thought it does have alot of flaws.

reviewText:
I've played this game before on GFWL and Xbox Live and thought it was very fun. However this version no matter what I did (-nod3d9, -nod3d10, disable overlay, vertify files, reinstall, delete save games, ect) the game on direct X 9 or 11 crashes immeditely even after a computer restart. It was some issue about external harddrives. I don't know why but this game WILL NOT PLAY if installed on an external HD. Once installed on the C:/ drive though everything worked flawless. This game runs and looks great and I have not come across any of the problems that I read about while searching for a solution to the HD issue. I will review the basic aspects of this version of the game: (not review the story ect. read another review)

DirectX11: Looks good and is a really nice update. I own a intel 2.8Ghz i7, AMD Radeon HD 5700 2GB vram, 8GB ram (4 year old computer)
-Game runs perfectly with no lag at all, even with Norton Security and other performance demanding apps.
-Quick load times, Cinematics work fine
-Still very fun game, no graphical issues or CTD at all during entire game. Destruction is good though one time during a mission my character jumped out of the verhicle in what I assume meant to be a dramatic scene where we avoided certain death instead my character catapulted directly into a death pit but the mission was still a success so it didn't bother me.
-Had issue with resolution once but didn't take long to fix. Devs say they are updating game often.
-Steam Overlay works fine, Downloading in-game works, overall transfer from GFWL to Steam is unnoticable
DirectX9: Didn't play the actual game on this mode after comfirmed working for DX11.


In the end a very good game and PC edition, only note is DO NOT buy if you don't wish to install on main drive; save yourself the time.

reviewText:
This was the second game I've played from the Red Faction franchise, right after the first Red Faction. They promised me destructibel environment, I got destructible environment, and I don't need an atomic reactor to run the game on. Tho sometimes it's a bit clunky, and you can break physics, but overall, destroying a building with only a big â™¥â™¥â™¥ hammer is really fun. And the better your hammer is, the more fun it becomes.

Graphics are a'rite. You are on Mars, so it's mostly red. Gives a great atmosphere, so it suits the game well.

Sounds are good. Voice actors gave a good and believable act, ambient sounds are cool. Again, suits the atmosphere of the game.

Story is while not the strongest, it gives a theme to why you wreck â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and have fun. You are the member of the Red Faction, a guerrilla movement on the planet Mars fightning against the Earth Defense Forces, or EDF. You have to clear each region before you can advance to the next to liberate them too. There are some storyline missions, but most of them are kind of fillers - destroy a building, ride shotgun for a crazy Red Faction member, bring a car back to the safehouse in a given timeframe, attack a building, defend a building. Thankfully they are varied, so you don't get bored, and not all of them are necessary to liberate an area. With every mission, EDF's presence in the area is weakened, and in the end, usually there's a mission where they retreat to the other area, and the one you've been in is freed. The final battle and the ending is again, not the best, but is really satifying.

Gameplay is where it shines. You can destroy basically EVERYTHING. And you have the tools for it. You smach things with your hammer. You explode things with rocket launchers. You have disc-launcher that shoots razorblades. You have a huge arc welder. And then, the best, the nano-forge. It basically melts ANYTHING it comes into contact with. Vehicles, personnel, building, what you want. Hit the thin spot of an airplane, and laugh while you watch it drop to the ground with a huge KABOOM. Other weapons include assault rifles, shotguns, the usual stuff. Most of them have upgrades too. There are a bunch of accessories in the game, like the warp to safehouse (good when you don't want to walk or drive), or the jump-pack. They are useful, but usually being fun is what matters. You can drive some vehicles, ranging from dumpster trucks to rocket launching tanks. Driving is sometimes tricky, and as well defined as in GTA (so to say, not the best), but then again, it's fun. And this is what this game really is: fun. It keeps you entertained, especially if you don't fail some of the missions for like 5-6 times like me. I'm glad I got the Red Faction bundle some time ago, as Guerrilla is one of the most entertaining and fun games I've played in the recent years. A big thumbs up, we can only hope more of this.

reviewText:
Pretty fun open world game.  Demolishing things in creative ways is what you do.  There's also lots of driving.  You have remote charges, rocket launchers, mini-black hole bombs,  a gun that disassembles matter on the molecular level, and a sledgehammer.  There's a story about rebellion and oppression and fighting the system - but who cares?  You blow stuff up, you collect the scrap, and you upgrade weapons.  You can also electrocute the crew of a tank, killing them, and then steal their tank.

You do have to pick your battles.  You will get overwhelmed quickly if you spend too much time in one area.  Hit and run is a safe way to play.

Once you complete the story you can go back and replay or finish all of the side missions of which there is a good variety.  Some are boring and involve too much driving, but others involve a lot of fun blowing things or piloting big robots.

reviewText:
This is truly one of my favourite games.

The single player is an invigorating experience like no other, liberating sector after sector and facing increasingly militarized hostility. The way the revolution is played out is up to your choices to upgrade your skills and purchased new weapons, the way you inspired your fellow guerrillas, and your overall combat skills. Driving the surface of terraformed Mars, you are revealed to structure after structure that can be destroyed with whatever means you choose! The freedom Havok physics engine provides is just another fantastic edition to this revolutionary game. With such a stimulating and realistic environment, Red Faction Guerrilla single player provides an extraordinary and unique, freeworld campaign that many other games attempt to strive for. Red Faction Guerrilla achieves this.

Its multiplayer is one of the most colourful and sublime multiplayers I've ever played. Instead of the monotonous Call of Duty kill-die-respawn pattern that we've all played before, it allows you to kill creatively with weapons that no other game has ever coneceived but still require tactics to use; not just anybody can pick up the Grinder and slice people up with it. Plus, the multitude of objective gametypes that are found in no other game (simply due to the fact that Red Faction Guerilla is so unlike every other game and therefore its objective gametypes can only be based around RFG's mechanics) adds variety to each game you play. The multiplayer never gets old. It is well worth it.

This game's population must be maintained. On the Xbox, its popularity has diminshed a point of no rejuvination. This game is well worth the $20, and when it's on sale don't hesitate to pick it up!

reviewText: With Red Faction: Guerrilla, players return to Mars to once more stir up trouble in an open-world game promising unheralded destruction from a third-person perspective. GFWL has been removed and the game has been integrated into Steam - Multiplayer, Achievements and all! Plenty of other games have done destructible environments, but never to this degree. Not only is virtually every man-made item in the game breakable, it breaks in detail. When you take your sledgehammer to a wall you break away the outer shell first, then you start digging into the concrete, and finally you hit rebar. Not only is the game's destruction fun to deliver and watch, but it also has a pretty big impact on how you play the game. When tasked with an assassination, you can sneak in and shoot the target or just take down the whole building the person is in. Tired of enemies sending reinforcements over a bridge? Take down the whole bridge. The level of destruction in Red Faction: Guerrilla deepens gameplay in ways I never would have imagined! Your best friend is the sledgehammer! The coolest looking is the singularity bomb which sucks the surrounding area into a small gravity well. Did I mention open world and massive scale? You can roam around and unlock new areas, new missions, new weapons. You get to demolish entire towns and design all the destruction as you see fit. My personal opinion is that this installment is the best one out of all the current Red Faction games!

reviewText:
Viva la revolution! The Red Faction franchise returns to Mars in the year 2120 to find the Earth Defense Force (EDF) twisted and corrupted into the very thing they helped to destroy in the oppressive corporation known as Ultor. The Red Faction rises once again! Resistant as ever and never willing to lay down quietly!

Volition, Inc. waste no time in throwing the player headfirst into the coup to overtake the EDF, giving players a very early taste of the destructive appeal of Red Faction: Guerrilla's gameplay. From there on it's liberating time--through a series of raids, assassinations, vandalism, and the occasional full out assault.

Red Faction: Guerrilla's gameplay styles itself after the Grand Theft Auto franchise, featuring a free roaming open world, alert levels and EDF responses to any of the player's hostile actions, a slew of both small and large missions, oh--and not to mention the fact that anything man made can be destroyed. The gaming world is made up of six different zones, as well as a seventh zone reserved for the end of the game. Each zone has two unique meters indicating the progress made towards liberating the zone. The most essential is the Control meter, which measures the EDF's total control over a given zone. The second is the morale meter--the higher the meter, the more perks you receive from colonists residing within the zone. The Grand Theft Auto nature of the game really comes through in the raising of the morale bar and the dropping of the control bar. The player is left to decide what they will do to get the job done. Destroying buildings owned by the EDF will reduce their control, however the buildings that yield the biggest net change in control are often deep within EDF territory forcing the player to fight their way through an entire base and then destroy the target building on top of that. There are also other types of missions, raids, rescuing hostages, assassinating targets, and helping colonists raid EDF controlled bases. All of these fill out to make a fun guerrilla warfare style of gameplay.

Sounds fun, right? Well it is, very much so. Unfortunately the EDF doesn't like you having fun with their property. As you destroy their structures, blow up their vehicles, and kill their personnel your alert level will rise. The alert level signifies how badly the EDF currently wants to put an end to your rampaging ways. So even if you make your way to the back of an EDF base to destroy a command center, you may be left with no easy means of escape, with airships, tanks, and EDF troops raining death down upon you as you leg your way out of the camp.

Volition nails this overall style of play which really draws the player into the spirit of revolution. This guerrilla warfare style of gameplay simply put is fun, just pure mindless fun. This is in no small part due to Volition's good job of complementing this style of gameplay with the franchise's most notable feature--the ability to destroy anything man-made. Going around destroying things like the badass you are is easily the numero uno element that makes the gameplay fun.

Guerrilla sticks to it's roots and once again features another story focused around a worker uprising on Mars. Although the story may not be anything exceptional, it is still really good in it's ability to support the guerrilla style gameplay the game gets it's name from. As mentioned before you really feel like you're part of a revolution, and that's half in part due to the gameplay as mentioned and half in part due to the story. You won't find the voice acting or dialog found in a game like Portal 2, but you'll still find something that works and get's the job done.

Red Faction: Guerrilla offers so much unbridled fun. Between a guerrilla warfare style of gameplay and a destructive sandbox world this is easily the game to try in the Red Faction franchise. So what are you waiting for? Come join the revolution!

You get rocket launchers, remote charges to throw at things, really cool vehicles and big explosions when you take stuff out. The EDF try really hard to kill you and your guerrilla compatriots and also they use terrain pretty sensibly, but the man made stuff can be destroyed and so it works in your favour if you gat a couple of troopers hidsing behind one wall. Boom and the trouble is gone.
The missions are well spaced out making you travel around to find all the stuff and although there is a storyline it does not drag you along by the nose, you have a lot of freedom to find your own targets.
Would I recommend this game? Most definitely yes. Can I find any flaws? Yes, there are lots of video issues but turning off DX10 gets rid of 99 % of these. To stop DX10 add -nod3d10 to the startup commands through Steam.
I am nowhere finished yet as I have been wandering off looking for stuff to destroy on my own, according to the stats I kill mostly with the assault rifle but enjoy hitting stuff real hard with the sledge hammer. Just unlocked the rocket launcher and this is fun but I mostly like the hammer and remote charges.

reviewText:
Pretty fun open world game.  Demolishing things in creative ways is what you do.  There's also lots of driving.  You have remote charges, rocket launchers, mini-black hole bombs,  a gun that disassembles matter on the molecular level, and a sledgehammer.  There's a story about rebellion and oppression and fighting the system - but who cares?  You blow stuff up, you collect the scrap, and you upgrade weapons.  You can also electrocute the crew of a tank, killing them, and then steal their tank.

You do have to pick your battles.  You will get overwhelmed quickly if you spend too much time in one area.  Hit and run is a safe way to play.

Once you complete the story you can go back and replay or finish all of the side missions of which there is a good variety.  Some are boring and involve too much driving, but others involve a lot of fun blowing things or piloting big robots.

reviewText:
This was the second game I've played from the Red Faction franchise, right after the first Red Faction. They promised me destructibel environment, I got destructible environment, and I don't need an atomic reactor to run the game on. Tho sometimes it's a bit clunky, and you can break physics, but overall, destroying a building with only a big â™¥â™¥â™¥ hammer is really fun. And the better your hammer is, the more fun it becomes.

Graphics are a'rite. You are on Mars, so it's mostly red. Gives a great atmosphere, so it suits the game well.

Sounds are good. Voice actors gave a good and believable act, ambient sounds are cool. Again, suits the atmosphere of the game.

Story is while not the strongest, it gives a theme to why you wreck â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and have fun. You are the member of the Red Faction, a guerrilla movement on the planet Mars fightning against the Earth Defense Forces, or EDF. You have to clear each region before you can advance to the next to liberate them too. There are some storyline missions, but most of them are kind of fillers - destroy a building, ride shotgun for a crazy Red Faction member, bring a car back to the safehouse in a given timeframe, attack a building, defend a building. Thankfully they are varied, so you don't get bored, and not all of them are necessary to liberate an area. With every mission, EDF's presence in the area is weakened, and in the end, usually there's a mission where they retreat to the other area, and the one you've been in is freed. The final battle and the ending is again, not the best, but is really satifying.

Gameplay is where it shines. You can destroy basically EVERYTHING. And you have the tools for it. You smach things with your hammer. You explode things with rocket launchers. You have disc-launcher that shoots razorblades. You have a huge arc welder. And then, the best, the nano-forge. It basically melts ANYTHING it comes into contact with. Vehicles, personnel, building, what you want. Hit the thin spot of an airplane, and laugh while you watch it drop to the ground with a huge KABOOM. Other weapons include assault rifles, shotguns, the usual stuff. Most of them have upgrades too. There are a bunch of accessories in the game, like the warp to safehouse (good when you don't want to walk or drive), or the jump-pack. They are useful, but usually being fun is what matters. You can drive some vehicles, ranging from dumpster trucks to rocket launching tanks. Driving is sometimes tricky, and as well defined as in GTA (so to say, not the best), but then again, it's fun. And this is what this game really is: fun. It keeps you entertained, especially if you don't fail some of the missions for like 5-6 times like me. I'm glad I got the Red Faction bundle some time ago, as Guerrilla is one of the most entertaining and fun games I've played in the recent years. A big thumbs up, we can only hope more of this.

reviewText:
This is truly one of my favourite games.

The single player is an invigorating experience like no other, liberating sector after sector and facing increasingly militarized hostility. The way the revolution is played out is up to your choices to upgrade your skills and purchased new weapons, the way you inspired your fellow guerrillas, and your overall combat skills. Driving the surface of terraformed Mars, you are revealed to structure after structure that can be destroyed with whatever means you choose! The freedom Havok physics engine provides is just another fantastic edition to this revolutionary game. With such a stimulating and realistic environment, Red Faction Guerrilla single player provides an extraordinary and unique, freeworld campaign that many other games attempt to strive for. Red Faction Guerrilla achieves this.

Its multiplayer is one of the most colourful and sublime multiplayers I've ever played. Instead of the monotonous Call of Duty kill-die-respawn pattern that we've all played before, it allows you to kill creatively with weapons that no other game has ever coneceived but still require tactics to use; not just anybody can pick up the Grinder and slice people up with it. Plus, the multitude of objective gametypes that are found in no other game (simply due to the fact that Red Faction Guerilla is so unlike every other game and therefore its objective gametypes can only be based around RFG's mechanics) adds variety to each game you play. The multiplayer never gets old. It is well worth it.

This game's population must be maintained. On the Xbox, its popularity has diminshed a point of no rejuvination. This game is well worth the $20, and when it's on sale don't hesitate to pick it up!

reviewText:
Red Faction: Guerilla was one of my all time favourite games for the XBOX 360. It has the best destruction engine I have ever seen in a game, including Frostbite. And whats more, it was incredibly fun! SIngle player could occationally get repetitive, and the racing mission were such a pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ (but I don't like racing in open world games anyway), but the awesome destruction NEVER got old. Throw in some great weapons with which to cause mayhem and you've got yourself bags of fun for hours on end.

And that's only the single player the Guerilla multiplayer was one of the most underrated parts of his massively underrated game. It was quick but not twitchy simple but not without lots of strategic and tactical options. Your combination of which superpowered backpack and which gun you chose to use would drastically change your play style. My personal favourite combo was the Rhino pack combined with the electric gun. You could smash through a wall taking out a passing player then finish them off by frying them with the elecric gun. So awesome!

I was gutted when the new call of duty came out (whichever one it was at the time) as there seemed to be a mass exodus on  xbox to tath, leaving me and my mates without anyone to play with or against. An unfortunately recurring problem with consoles.

So when I saw it on steam I though GREAT! PC gamers are way more likely to keep this online stuff going! Only to find out it was a GFWL game and that it'll be going the way of the dodo very soon. So dissapointing!

Red Faction: Guerilla is a brilliant game basically. But with very little incentive to play it any more....such a shame.

reviewText:
The story is paper thin and laughable, just like the walls of buildings you'll be knocking down with your Mjolnir-like sledgehammer.  But the combat and physics are top notch; it's SO satisfying when enemies are entrenched in buildings to just destroy the entire building instead of carefully sneaking through each corridor and hallway.  The campaign is long and varied and I've found myself setting RF:G down for several months, then reinstalling it just to play through again and laugh in delight as I set elaborate traps up for the security forces foolish enough to mess with me.

There's a few failings in the game, but I feel nitpicky pointing them out.  Sometimes the AI is dumb.  The in-game grass has a laughably short drawing distance, making it look like the ground is kind of boiling while you drive across it.  And while the missions are varied, some are just annoyingly long with frustratingly few checkpoints.

Overall, it's a great game.  Fun, mindless destruction on a huge map.

reviewText: I really enjoyed destroying stuff in this game.  Often, I would stop playing the campaign for hours and just destroy as many things as possible with a sledgehammer.  It sounds silly, but it's obessively fun.\nStory itself is so-so and there isn't really any serious drama involved except maybe in some spooky places in the middle of the game in the desert.  Controls took a little getting used to - driving can be difficult if you are not good a driving games.  And there is a TON of driving. reviewText:
I played this game whilst it was on steam for free, so it is not a game I would have bought on my own and won't have as much playtime experience with it

OverviewRed Faction Guerrilla feels like a post apocalyptic game set on a distant future earth. No actually, its on mars. The game immediatley shoves the emphasis on fun and being able to destroy everything you see whilst gawping at the games great physics destruction effects. Literally, everything you see that isnt part of the terrian (i.e. cars, buildings, fences) can be destroyed using the various arsenal of weapons including explosive charges and your trusty sledgehammer. The story is nothing particularly exciting and SPOILERS will follow. This game isn't based on giving you an intense, jaw dropping story based ecperience and has a pretty run-of-the-mill sotryline. The world is basically being held captive by an opressive evil government, your brother is part of the resistance group and he gets killed in pretty much the opening cutscene (the second one). END OF SPOILERS The characters that the game throws at you are pretty run of the mill, but that in no way ruins the experience of the game. It delivers satisfying destruction and fun gunplay and should not be ignored.

Positive
+ Great Destruction
+ Graphics are OK
+ Fun Gameplay

Negative
- Boring Story
- Un-interesting Characters

ConclusionIf you are looking for a story driven epic, just ignore this game. If you are looking to blow some stuff up and have a little bit of fun, then this game is probably a safe bet for you.

reviewText: I got lost in this game. The physics gameplay makes this game unique and unrivaled in it's genre, yes, you get a massive open world to enjoy but more that that... You can enter every building and destroy it wall by wall. See a bridge, you can destroy it, see a massive sky-scraper... DESTROY IT! And what's more that that is that you feel like everything you destroy will somehow affect the storyline in some way. And it does. The weapons make you feel powerful in this game, heck, even swinging a hammer will be rewarding because it actually does something to the environment lol\n\nThe only complaint is that the game feels empty sometimes. While it's fun to drive around and blow $#!t up, there's really nobody to interact or talk with other than the main story missions. Side quests consists of you smashing stuff, but alone. You're on Mars and the devs really make you feel that lol Still, the storyline is a great one. The game is fun and I wouldn't mind doing it all over again.

reviewText:
GTA: Mars For a game released in 2009, it holds up both technically and in terms of gameplay. If you've played this game on console and are worried about the port quality: don't be.

Gameplay Solid third person shooter mechanics, incredible destruction and destructive physics. Vehicles are a little floaty but you're on Mars now baby, what do you expect?

Visuals For a 2009 game? Are you kidding me? Solid as hell.

Sound Buildings under stress creak and groan. Guns are punchy. Enemy soldiers crunch when you hit them with a sledgehammer or run them over in a rover. Voice acting is alright. The soundtrack is at a quite enjoyable level of cheese.

Story Story is not anything incredible. But you're not playing this game for the story, are you? You're here to blow â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ up. It gets the job done.

Multiplayer Thoroughly dead. However, it is fun when you can get game going. So grab a few of your mates for a good time.

Replayability Open world, Lots of collectable" type stuff.  Cheat codes.

CONCLUSION If you're on the fence about buying this game
date: it generally goes on sale for about $4 USD (and is on sale as of this writing). The game is fantastic and I wholeheartedly recommend it. The game knows what it does well (destruction mechanics) and doubles down on it. If its any indication of how much I enjoy this game
recommended: I had played it for many hours when it first came out on the Xbox 360
hoursPlayed: and have just now purchased it to replay on my PC."
